speaker: therapist
text: Welcome to our final scheduled session. I want to acknowledge right from the start that this is a significant moment. How are you feeling coming in today?

speaker: client
text: A mix of things. Proud, I think. And grateful. But also a little nervous about what happens after this. Like I'm graduating but I'm not sure I've learned everything.

speaker: therapist
text: That's completely natural. Therapy isn't about learning 'everything'—it's about building a foundation and a toolkit. Today is about reviewing that foundation and making a plan for how you'll continue building on your own. Shall we start by looking back at where we began?

speaker: client
text: Yes, that would be good. It feels like a long time ago.

speaker: therapist
text: In our first session, you described feeling stuck in a heavy fog, overwhelmed by feelings or feeling nothing at all, with reactions that felt disproportionate and confusing. The core work you identified was building awareness and managing intense feelings. Looking at that now, what feels different?

speaker: client
text: The fog has lifted. Not completely—there are still cloudy days—but I can see through it now. I understand the weather patterns, if that makes sense. I know that when I snap or go numb, it's a signal, not a character flaw. I have a map now where before I was just lost.

speaker: therapist
text: That's a powerful metaphor—having a map of your own emotional landscape. Can you describe one or two of the most important landmarks on that map?

speaker: client
text: The biggest one is recognizing the '12-year-old'—that part of me that learned his worth was conditional. He's not running the show anymore, but I know when he's activated. The second landmark is the 'compassionate bodyguard' or the 'adult self'—the part that can hold space, that says 'I see you, we're okay.' That's the part I'm strengthening.

speaker: therapist
text: Beautifully said. And what about the tools? The focusing technique, the two-chair dialogue, the 'now or then' question—which have become most integrated into your daily life?

speaker: client
text: The 'now or then' check is almost automatic now. It's like a quick mental scan that stops the spiral. And the focusing—just pausing to feel where the emotion is in my body and being curious about it—that's become my go-to instead of either exploding or imploding. I don't do the full two-chair dialogue alone, but sometimes I have those internal conversations in my journal.

speaker: therapist
text: That's excellent integration. You've moved these from therapy exercises to lived practices. Now, I'm curious about relationships. How has this internal shift affected your connection with your partner, or others?

speaker: client
text: It's night and day. With my partner, I'm less reactive. I can ask for what I need without shame, and I can hear her needs without feeling attacked. It's not perfect—we still have disagreements—but they don't feel like existential threats anymore. I've even been able to set a boundary with my dad for the first time, kindly but firmly. That felt like a milestone.

speaker: therapist
text: That is a tremendous milestone. It demonstrates that your sense of worth is becoming internal, not dependent on his approval. This is the essence of secure attachment in adulthood. Now, let's look forward. What do you see as potential challenges or vulnerable areas?

speaker: client
text: Major stressors. A job loss, a big argument, a period of depression. I worry that under enough pressure, I might revert to old patterns. And... maintaining this practice without the structure of our weekly sessions.

speaker: therapist
text: Those are very realistic concerns. Let's make a concrete plan. First, for maintenance: what small, non-negotiable practice will you commit to, like brushing your teeth, to keep this foundation strong?

speaker: client
text: Five minutes of journaling every morning. Just checking in with myself—what do I feel, what do I need? And if I notice I'm avoiding it, that's a signal in itself.

speaker: therapist
text: Perfect. Second, for high-stress times: what will be your early warning sign that you're getting dysregulated, and what will be your first step?

speaker: client
text: Early warning is physical—that tightness in my chest or the urge to isolate. First step is to name it out loud to myself: 'I'm feeling overwhelmed.' Then, do the focusing exercise, even if it's just 60 seconds. If that doesn't help, I have a list of supportive people I can reach out to.

speaker: therapist
text: Excellent. You have a tiered response plan. And remember, returning to therapy for a 'tune-up' session or a short series during difficult times is always a sign of strength, not failure. It's like seeing a doctor when you have the flu—you're using the resource appropriately.

speaker: client
text: That's good to know. It makes the idea of ending feel less absolute.

speaker: therapist
text: Exactly. This isn't an ending of support; it's a transition to you being your own primary support, with professional help as a backup system. Now, I'd like to do a brief final exercise. Close your eyes. Imagine yourself six months from now, living with this integrated wisdom. What do you see?

speaker: client
text: (Closes eyes, smiles slightly) I see someone who is... steadier. Who has hard days but doesn't get lost in them. Who can be genuinely present with the people he loves because he's not constantly managing internal chaos. There's a sense of quiet confidence, not in being perfect, but in being resilient.

speaker: therapist
text: That's a beautiful vision. Hold onto that. You have done the courageous work to make it possible. Before we close, I want to offer some final reflections. You came in feeling broken, and you discovered you were simply wounded and unskilled. You have shown remarkable courage in facing those wounds and diligence in building new skills. The relationship you've built with yourself is now your greatest resource.

speaker: client
text: (Eyes moist) Thank you. That means more than I can say. Thank you for giving me the map and teaching me how to read it. I feel like I'm leaving with my own compass.

speaker: therapist
text: You absolutely are. It has been a privilege to walk this part of the journey with you. I have every confidence in your ability to continue. Remember your practices, your plan, and your vision. Be well.

speaker: client
text: I will. Thank you, and goodbye.
